content.description: Pitch1: Climb the southwest face past two bolts to the prominent "fangs". Traverse right below the limestone band to gain the ledge. Continue up a right-facing dihedral to a ledge. Pitch2: Continue up a face past four more bolts and some smaller gear to the summit.
content.location: Continue past the Siamese Twins and around to the southwest side of the next spire.

content.description:
Choss! This route gets one star because the summit is amazing.  Small, perfectly flat and sporting amazing views.  This spire was originally attempted in 2004 by Jake Dayley and Chris Tatum and later that year with Dustin Wildermuth.  These attempts failed due to poor rock, spinning bolts and vaginal sand.

 Locate the South facing crack system and climb up ever steepening terrain.  After the 4th bolt the route veers right into worsening choss. Tiptoe past a mudball and into the relative security of a squeeze chimney.  Continue up the squeeze with ease to the crux OW roof/mantle. Cruise to the excellent summit. Terrible rock but good pro or bolts when you need them.  

 Rap: 70' down the North side to the notch.

 Rack: Doubles to #3.  Singles - #4, #5.  An assortment of draws/slings. One 60m rope. Helmet!
content.protection: Mixed pro and bolts.  Bolted anchor.
content.location:
Spinner Spire is located below the Land of Spires in the large amphitheater atop the drainage*

 Approach 1.0-1.5 hours. Follow the Long Canyon trail for 30-40 minutes (crossing the creek twice) to a point where the trail nears the creek.  You'll pass a stand of large dead Cypress trees just before this point. Leave the trail to enter the wash and locate the small tributary that heads up to the Land of Spires and Sock Puppet Spire area.  At the fork in the stream go right towards Land of Spires. Prepare to thrash. Pass through an incredible overhanging amphitheater and continue up. The first drainage to the right (climbers) of Spinner Spire goes but requires a 12 foot 5.8 boulder problem.  Easier to continue right, in the ever shrinking drainage all the way up and through a sandstone cliff band, then traverse left several hundred feet to the spire.  Walk all the way around to the South side to find the route.

climbs.name: South Siamese Twin: South Twin Route

content.description: This route shares a start, then continues left at the end of the first pitch.
content.protection: Gear to 5" + one 6' piece. Fixed anchors.
content.location: From the approach trail, go below and past the twins, then head up the east side. From the split of the towers, See topo.

content.description: Climb a ramp to a right-leaning crack with a left-facing dihedral above. See topo. There is a top-rope route on the west side called "Palm Reader" that one can climb from the base of the rappel.
content.location: From the approach trail branch off down from the base of the south Siamese Twin to the east side of the spire below.

content.description: Climb the north face past some bolts and gear.
content.protection: Standard Sedona rack & 4 bolts. Fixed anchor.
content.location: From the split in the twins, continue north via an easy traverse to the north side. See topo.

content.description: This route shares a start, then continues left at the end of the first pitch. The second pitch continues to a right-facing dihedral, followed by a spicy slab to the summit.
content.location: From the approach trail, go below and past the twins, then head up the east side. From the split of the towers, See topo.

content.description: The Land of Spires is a collection of aesthetic towers poised on the ridge lining the eastern edge of the mouth of Long Canyon. First explored by John Burcham, these obscure summits don't see much traffic. Expect solitude.
